title.narrative: 06.4 SEVERE ACUTE MALNUTRITION

description.narrative: 2014-16 output 6.4: By 2016, relevant health facilities have the capacity to operationalize the approved acute malnutrition guidelines in selected areas and in emergency affected areas as per CCCs. 2011-13 Old Intermediate Results (IR) 9.4 By 2015, relevant health facilities have the capacity to operationalize the approved acute malnutrition guidelines in selected areas and in emergency as per CCCs., which contributes to Community-Based Management Of Acute Malnutrition, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: 2013 - 2016 Outcome 06: By 2016, the Government implements a comprehensive sustainable nutrition programme including adequate Infant and Young Child Feeding (IYCF), Micronutrients and Management of Acute Malnutrition programmes2011 - 2013 Programme Component Results (PCR) 9: By 2015, child and maternal nutrition improved at local and national levels. (By 2015, the Government implement a comprehensive sustainable nutrition programme including adequate Infant and Young Child Feeding, Micronutrients and Management of Acute Malnutrition programs)

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: 2014-16 output 6.4: By 2016, relevant health facilities have the capacity to operationalize the approved acute malnutritionguidelines in selected areas and in emergency affected areas as per CCCs. 2011-13 Old IR 9.4 By 2015, relevant health facilitieshave the capacity to operationalize the approved acute malnutrition guidelines in selected areas and in emergency as per CCCs.

description.narrative: Nutrition services to screen, refer and treat acute malnutrition among children aged under 5 were scaled up from 89 to 189 counties nationwide (up from 60 per cent coverage in 2015 to 90 per cent in 2016), making CMAM services accessible to 1.5 million out of 1.7 million U5 children. | Status:Met | As-of Date:09/01/2017

title.narrative: 6.4.b. No stock-out of CMAM supplies for the management of severe acute malnutrition at the central and provincial medical warehouses

actual.value: 2017:UNICEF facilitated in-country logistics through quarterly distribution of all therapeutic and nutrition supplies. No stock-out reported in 2016.

title.narrative: (NOT VALID after Dec 31 2017) ) Children aged 6-59 months with SAM targeted by UNICEF-support (financial or supplies) who are admitted for treatment in the reporting year (in non- humanitarian situations)

actual.value: 2017:Over 60,000 SAM children treated in 2016. Nutrition services to screen, refer and treat acute malnutrition among children aged under 5 were scaled up from 89 to 189 counties nationwide (up from 60 per cent coverage in 2015 to 90 per cent in 2016), making CMAM services accessible to 1.5 million out o

title.narrative: 6.4.a. Percent of health facilities in selected areas with trained health workers at all levels

actual.value: 2017:The nutrition services are expanded to 189 out of 210 counties. About 2-3 doctors per facility were trained representing about 20% of the manpower. In 2016, UNICEF facilitated a total of nine workshops on IYCF and CMAM: three in Pyongyang for district general hospitals, two in Kaesong for provincial
